column1: We constantly link different things together: new kids and their names
column3: green eggs and ham. How does our brain achieve this? The purpose of this study was to understand how the brain creates these links. What happens in brain cells when we learn that two things (e.g.
column4: a new kid and her name) go together? In an experiment we asked human participants to learn to link different items together. As the participants learned these links
column5: we found that nerve cells in their brains also linked these items together. These nerve cells were found in a region of the brain called the hippocampus. In this article
column6: we will first explain how it is possible to listen to nerve cells in the human brain. Then we will show some examples of the responses of these nerve cells
column8: how the cells can link different items together.
